Erika Sauter
Freelance Literary Journalist, storyteller, Iowan, emotional eater and DIY enthusiast. I love libraries, books and handwritten letters from pen pals.
Apr 8

Held Up at Gun Point

The Day I Walked Away

I slammed the phone down, grabbed my coat and hurried outside to hail a cab. I stood there on the street, camouflaged in the chaos of the city as cabs continued to drive past me. My heart was racing as I stepped off of the curb and into the street. I had to be the first one there. I could hardly breathe. I’ve been hanging from a thread already and messing this up will do me in. I waved my arm with a rapid motion until a cab finally came to a halt, brakes screeching. I jumped into the cab.

“The fastest route to the corner of 47th and Roosevelt, please.”

His eyes flashed at me in the rearview mirror. “Yes ma’am,” the driver said. “I’ll do my best.”

Ten minutes had gone by and we’d hardly made it two blocks. Rush hour traffic was monstrous. Horns were honking, drivers were yelling out their windows and bicyclist were weaving in and out of stopped cars.

“I’ll get out here,” I said as I threw a twenty on the front seat and got out of the car. I booked it up over the curb and went running down the sidewalk.

As I approached the building, there were police cars parked up and down the street, lights flashing. A SWAT van pulled up on the curb and an ambulance off in the distance, parked in the street on the next block.

Jacobs and Hager were already there. I’m screwed, I thought. As I approached I noticed Hager looked unusually exhausted. He wore dark patches beneath his eyes. Jacobs looked like his every day pretty boy self. He beamed his smile at me as I drew closer. My heart sunk knowing they got here before me.

“So what’s the scoop, boys? I hoped they would give me details I could send in.

“Not much to tell yet, Bell. They holed themselves up in the bank,” Jacobs informed me.

“They’ve got hostages in there,” Hager said. “The police are looking for a way in while they distract them with the negotiations.”

“I heard gunshots when I first got here,” Jacobs chimed, “but the police don’t want to rush the building to avoid hostages from getting hurt.”

The bank was an old cobblestone building. It was solid concrete inside and out. The windows were tinted making it impossible to see inside. Rust colored water stains ran down the building where drain pipes were clogged. A K-9 now stood where the doorman once was.

I decided to head around the block. If I didn’t show up with a lead the boss was going to have my head.

I walked around the building looking for anything that stood out. Perhaps an eyewitness or clues that led to the robbers themselves. That’s when I noticed it. A white minivan with out-of-state plates. Before approaching, I checked my surrounds; no one was looking. I hustled over to the van and opened the door. I looked up and there was a gun in my face. “Move and you’ll regret it.”

He spoke quietly, the anger of his words being forced through his teeth. He was tall, lanky and not wearing a mask. My body froze. I was doing my best not to look him in the eyes. I kept my head down and stared at the ground.

“Who are you?” He demanded.

“My name is Lidia Bell,” I quivered. “I’m a reporter for the Chicago Gazette.”

“How did you know I was in here?”

“I didn’t. I suspected the van may be associated with the robbery so I walked over to check it out.”

“You can step back now. Let’s go.”

It occurred to me that I had seen his face. The chances of him letting me go were bleak.

“What’s the best way out of here without anyone seeing me?”

I stood silent. He nudged my shoulder with the gun.

“Look at me when I’m talking to you.”

I turned to face him and he looked me dead center in the eyes. I noticed something moving above his head. I glanced up. It was a man dressed in a SWAT uniform moving his hand in a down motion.

“What are you looking at?”

“Nothing,” I said but he didn’t believe me. As he turned to look I ducked. A sniper from the roof top behind me shot him in the shoulder and he went down. I couldn’t move. Every muscle in my body seized.

I snapped to when he sat up. His torso covered in his blood. I ran. As I came around the side of the building I crashed straight into the officer that had signaled me to duck. “Are you alright, miss?”

“What?” My thoughts were scrambled.

“I want you to get checked out by the medics.” he said. He took me by the arm and walked me over.

I scowled. “I don’t need a medic. I need to get downtown.”

He sat me down on the edge of the ambulance. I saw the boss roughly 30 feet away. The medic looked me over and quickly saw that I was okay physically.

The boss approached. “You doing alright, Bell?”

“Yeah. I’m good.”

“Did you get the scoop?”

“Which one? The robbers holed up inside the bank or the one where the getaway guy put a gun on me before getting taken down by a sniper?”

“The bank. Bell. Did you get any info about the bank?”

What I’d experienced hadn’t even fazed him.

“Nope. I must have missed that, Boss,” I said through grinding teeth.

“I know after the hostages were released SWAT rushed in and nabbed the robbers,” he said. “Looks like Hager and Jacobs got another story.”

“I guess so,” I responded.

Hours later I was sitting at my desk in the center of the newsroom. My heart was racing and my thoughts were fuzzy. Keep it together, Lidia. The clickity clank of fingertips beating on keyboards were growing louder. The room was closing in on me. It was shrinking. Don’t freak out, don’t.

“Bell, do you not hear me?” The boss hollered. “Hello Bell, come back to planet earth.”

“What do you want Boss?”

“Sorry to interrupt your daydream. I want you to come in my office.”

I locked my computer as if I had written something of any importance and needed to hide it. As I walked across the newsroom everyone stared. They all knew what happened to me. That’s the thing with journalists: news travels fast. I walked into the boss’s office and closed the door.

“I’ll give you front page, Bell”

“I told you at the bank, I didn’t get any details. Hager and Jacobs should get front page.”

“I’m not talking about the robbery, Bell.”

I knew what he meant but I didn’t want to acknowledge him. I felt my legs shaking. I tried to settle them with no avail. I stood up to make it stop.

I walked over to the window and looked down at the traffic nine floors below me. The sun was starting to set and the sky looked back at me with shades of yellow and purple. I couldn’t feel the sun through the thick window glass but I knew it was warm. I saw the strength in its glow.

Boss broke the silence. “I want the story on my desk by 8:00 pm.” He was commanding me to do something I wasn’t going to do.

“No.” I took a deep breath. The air expanded my lungs. As I exhaled I said, “No,” again. This time more stern.

“What are you talking about, Bell?”

“How long we been working together, Boss?”

“Lidia.”

“How long, Boss?”

“Geez, a decade or so.”

I filled with anger, my blood rising to a boil. I walked back toward him and put my hands on his desk. “How could you ask me to write the story?”

“I offered front page.”

“You offered front because I had a gun in my face, only five hours ago. I won’t write the story. I refuse.”

“You’re being irrational.”

Keep yourself together, Bell. I tried but I couldn’t. A wave took over me. “You think not writing the story is irrational?” I was yelling now.

“Don’t push me, Bell.”

“Don’t push you?” I stood silent. The events of the morning were flashing through my mind. I didn’t know where to go from here or how to rid myself of it. “I quit. How’s that for irrational?”

The slight breeze from storming away caused papers to rise from the top of his desk. I slammed the door behind me. I went back to my desk, pulled out a box of old copy prints and dumped them onto the floor. I swept the length of my arm across my desk and pushed my stuff in the box. I tore my badge off my lapel and threw it on the desk. It slid until the computer monitor stopped it.

I grabbed the box and walked away.
